titlestmt.subtitle: A Finding Aid to the Louis Wiesenberg Papers, 1913-1981, in the Archives of American Art
titlestmt.author: by Jean Fitzgerald

publicationstmt.publisher: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Stephanie Ashley on April 25, 2007

did.head: Collection Overview

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution

did.abstract: The scattered papers of Louis Wiesenberg measure 0.6 linear feet and date from 1913-1981. Found are biographical materials, letters primarily from Louis' widow Raizel Wiesenberg, notes and writings, numerous drawings, printed material, and photographs of Wiesenberg, his family, and artwork.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Louis Wiesenberg papers were donated in 1981 and 1982 by Raizel Wiesenberg Arp, the artist's widow.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The papers were processed in February 2007 by Jean Fitzgerald.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Louis Wiesenberg papers, 1913-1981. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

userestrict.head: Ownership and Literary Rights
userestrict.p: The Louis Wiesenberg papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Louis Wiesenberg (1893-1943) was born in Poland and studied art in Montreal and at the National Academy of Design in New York. He settled in New York where he painted and drew. He later moved back to Montreal, but continued to exhibit in New York.

In 1909, Wiesenberg immigrated to Montreal, Canada, with his father and two sisters, leaving his mother and three other sisters in Poland until money could be sent for their passage. His father, who had studied painting in Paris, established a small paint shop in which Louis learned about paint, brushes, and other artistic tools.

After studying art at the Monument Nationale School in Montreal, Louis Wiesenberg continued his studies at the National Academy of Design in New York City in 1916. Following the death of his eldest sister in 1917, Wiesenberg returned to Montreal to assist in his father??s business, but continued to exhibit his artwork in Montreal, Ottawa, and New York.

In 1922 Wiesenberg married Raizel, a singer, and they eventually settled in New York City. They befriended many artists, including Milton Avery and Mark Rothko. In 1928, a series of portrait drawings of authors by Wiesenberg was published in the Herald Tribune. He also worked at various art-related jobs including teaching art at a children??s camp in order to make ends meet. During the Depression, Wiesenberg??s health began to fail.
Louis Wiesenberg died on December 22, 1943 in New York City.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers of painter Louis Wiesenberg measure 0.6 linear feet and date from 1913 to 1981. Found within the papers are biographical material; letters - mostly written by his widow Raizel Wiesenberg attempting to organize a posthumous exhibition; notes and writings, including manuscripts describing Wiesenberg??s thoughts on art; numerous drawings of figure studies and landscapes; printed material, including catalogs from exhibitions by obscure organizations such as the Level Club and the Society of Independent Artists; and photographs of Wiesenberg, his family and his artwork.

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This collection is indexed in the online catalog of the Archives of American Art under the following index terms.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.corpname: Society of Independent Artists (New York, N.Y.)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 6 series.

scopecontent.p: Biographical material consists of a National Academy of Design student identity card, a New York military census card, and a biographical manuscript written by Wiesenberg??s wife, Raizel.

did.unittitle: Identity Cards and Biographical Manuscript, 1916-1981, undated

scopecontent.p: Letters discuss art-related business and are primarily from Raizel Wiesenberg relating to her attempts to organize a posthumous exhibition of her husband??s work.
This series consists of manuscripts by Louis Wiesenberg concerning art-related topics, poems by Raizel Wiesenberg dedicated to her deceased husband, and miscellaneous notes.

did.unittitle: Drafts of "What is Art?" by Louis Wiesenberg, undated
Manuscript "Michelangelo Buonarotti" by Louis Wiesenberg, undated

scopecontent.p: Artwork by Wiesenberg consists of miscellaneous sketches in pencil, charcoal, and watercolor, torn from sketchbooks. Images include figure studies and landscapes.
Printed material consists of clippings and exhibition catalogs primarily from the Society of Independent Artists.
Photographs are of Wiesenberg, his family and his artwork. There is also a photograph of a portrait of Wiesenberg by Gershon Benjamin.

did.unittitle: Photographs of Wiesenberg and Family Members, 1920, undated
Photographs of Artwork by Wiesenberg, undated
Photograph of Portrait by Gershon Benjamin, undated
